intro: Rosa agrestis subvar. ditrichopoda, commonly known as the rough-stemmed wild rose, is a shrub native to temperate regions of Europe and western Asia. It typically grows in open woodlands, grasslands, and along stream banks, preferring well-drained soils. The plant features arching stems covered in stiff, glandular hairs, giving it a rough texture. Its leaves are pinnately compound, with 5–9 leaflets that are serrated and often hairy. The flowers are pale pink to white, with five petals, and appear in late spring to early summer.
